awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Optimal Prosthesis Design with Energy Regeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this research are three-fold: (1) To develop new approaches for the simulation of human limb control; (2) To develop new approaches for optimizing prosthetic limb control, capture energy during walking, and store that energy to lengthen useful prosthesis life; and (3) To develop a prosthesis prototype. In order to accomplish these high-level goals, the following specific objectives will be pursued: (1) Study both able-bodied gait and amputee gait in our human motion lab; (2) Develop mathematical models for human motion control to provide a foundation for artificial limb control; (3) Develop electronic prosthesis controls; (4) Develop new approaches for optimizing prosthesis design parameters based on computer intelligence; (5) Fabricate a prosthesis prototype and test the prototype in a robotic system; (6) Conduct human trials of the prosthesis prototype.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to new methods for optimizing complex, inter-related subsystems, such as those that are characteristic of prostheses. The human leg operates by transferring energy between the knee, which absorbs energy, and the ankle, which produces energy. The new prosthesis design that results from this research will mimic the energy transfer of the human leg. Inter-related engineering systems are typically designed and optimized independently of each other. This results in designs that are overly conservative, that do not interact optimally, and that limit performance, adaptability, and robustness. This research will develop integrated optimization algorithms that consider the inter-dependence of related subsystems (for example, hardware, software, and control). Current knee prostheses do not restore normal gait, and this contributes to degenerative joint disease among amputees. This research will develop new design and optimization approaches that will allow prostheses to perform more robustly, to perform closer to natural human gait, and to last longer between battery charges than current prostheses.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This research developed new types of methods to control the knee motor in an above-knee prosthesis. The control methods were based on the way that humans control their legs during walking. The prosthesis control methods were optimized to match, as closely as possible, the way that humans walk. The control methods were also optimized to extract the greatest possible amount of energy from the amputee’s walking motion so that the energy could be used to recharge the batteries, and so the prosthesis battery wouldn’t need to be recharged as often as it would otherwise. The prosthesis was simulated on a computer, tested on a robot, tested with able-bodied persons using a specialized prosthesis adapter, and finally tested with amputees. Tests show that the prosthesis can replicate the most important characteristics of human gait and that the prosthesis electronics can capture energy from the environment during walking. In fact, the energy regeneration methods were so efficient that the amputee would never need to recharge the battery, assuming that walking was restricted to level ground.

This research was important because there are over 400,000 above-knee amputees in the US, the amputee population is growing because of the prevalence of diabetes, and many amputees experience a downward spiral of declining health. Amputees are much more likely to experience debilitating back pain, to fall, and to experience other health problems, compared to able-bodied persons. More effective prostheses will enable amputees to be more active, participate more fully in society, lead healthier and safer lives, and experience a higher quality of life.

This research provided training opportunities for many graduate students and undergraduate students to learn how to do research under the supervision of faculty researchers. The research also provided opportunities for lab tours, demonstrations, and motivational experiences for hundreds of high school students each year who toured the researchers’ labs and became excited about the possibility of a career in engineering design and research.


Last Modified: 10/02/2018
Modified by: Dan Simon
